top.author: @EffZee_
top.text: I hate that this has to be said I have a girlfriend, donâ€™t dm asking me out, donâ€™t email me asking me out. Iâ€™m not interested, even if I was single, I wouldnâ€™t be interested. I am here to hopefully entertain, idc if you find me attractive.

options.comment: The fact that you have to set email boundaries for dating requests shows how wild the internet has gotten ğŸ˜…
Setting clear boundaries upfront actually saves everyone time and energy. Respect to you for being direct about it.
Email for dating requests? That's... a whole new level of inbox management challenges ğŸ“§

top.author: @FourEyedBae
top.text: I hate that this has to be said I have a boyfriend, donâ€™t dm asking me out, donâ€™t email me asking me out. Iâ€™m not interested, even if I was single, I wouldnâ€™t be interested. I am here to hopefully entertain, idc if you find me attractive.

options.comment: The fact that this needs to be said at all speaks volumes about the state of online interactions ğŸ˜¤
Boundaries are boundaries. The amount of unwanted DMs and emails people get is honestly exhausting to even think about.
This is why I appreciate platforms that let you filter who can message you. Should be the default everywhere.

top.author: @wisdomdyn
top.text: I hate that this has to be said I have a girlfriend, donâ€™t dm asking me out, donâ€™t email me asking me out. Iâ€™m not interested, even if I was single, I wouldnâ€™t be interested. I am here to hopefully entertain, idc if you find me attractive.

options.comment: The fact that you have to make a PSA about this says everything about internet boundaries (or lack thereof) ğŸ˜…
Setting clear boundaries upfront is actually brilliant - saves everyone time and awkwardness. More creators should normalize this kind of direct communication.
As someone who deals with too much unwanted communication daily, I feel this. The signal-to-noise ratio in DMs and emails can be brutal.

top.author: @ZDNET
top.text: This little-known Gmail trick gave me back 15GB and fixed my inbox chaos for free

options.comment: Plot twist: it was deleting those 47,000 unread newsletters you swore you'd read someday ğŸ“§
Storage reclaim is one thing, but the real win is breaking free from notification anxiety. Been thinking a lot about how inbox architecture affects our mental bandwidth.
15GB back is nice, but I'm more curious about the 'chaos fix' part. Most people focus on storage but miss how email overload fragments attention throughout the day.

top.author: @lambypies
top.text: Is it the same code that doesn't find emails you know are in your (Modestly sized) inbox and can't find any files anywhere on any of your drives either? Somehow it's so much worse when things used to work than when they broken too start with.

options.comment: The betrayal of a search function that used to work is a special kind of pain. It's like your computer developed selective amnesia but only for the stuff you actually need.
This hits deep. The degradation of basic search functionality feels like tech moving backwards. When you can't trust your tools to find what you put there, everything becomes manual archaeology.
The worst part is when you know exactly what you're looking for but the search gives you everything except that. Makes you wonder how much time we lose daily to broken search across all our tools.

top.author: @OurTownReno
top.text: Another Year, Another Terrible Death Toll for the Unhoused Among Us... Find a recap of our recent reporting plus bonus content such as this by email by signing up to receive our regular Our Town Reno Substack here: https:// ourtownreno.substack.com

options.comment: Important stories like this often get buried in our feeds. Thank you for keeping this visible and accessible.
This is exactly why local journalism matters. These stories need to be told and remembered.
The fact that we need newsletters to keep track of critical local issues says a lot about how information gets lost in the noise.

top.author: @Olawherz
top.text: I hate that this has to be said I have a girlfriend, donâ€™t dm asking me out, donâ€™t email me asking me out. Iâ€™m not interested, even if I was single, I wouldnâ€™t be interested. I am here to hopefully entertain, idc if you find me attractive.

options.comment: The fact that people still use email for sliding into DMs is somehow both vintage and concerning ğŸ˜…
Setting clear boundaries is so important. The internet makes people forget basic respect sometimes.
Email sliding is a whole different level of bold. At least DMs feel casual, but email? That's like... formal rejection territory ğŸ“§

top.author: @MarvinUchenna_
top.text: I once lost a gig cos I was sent a DM and it never came through until I went to spÃ¡m inbox to check after I got an email. Itâ€™s really sÃ¡d how Africans are treated both online and offline.

options.comment: Spam filters shouldn't be making life-changing decisions for us. Sorry this happened to you - these systems need to be way smarter about what actually matters.
Plot twist: the spam folder is where all the actual opportunities hide while our main inbox gets flooded with newsletters we forgot we signed up for ğŸ˜¤
This hits hard. Been thinking a lot about how broken our notification systems are - important stuff gets buried while noise gets through. We deserve better.

top.author: @Shpigford
top.text: i ship so much because i say no to everything else. i've optimized for exactly what i want. nobody wants a full calendar and an inbox full of pointless emails that they then need an AI to manage and summarize for them.

options.comment: The real optimization is training yourself to say no before the noise even reaches your inbox. Prevention > curation.
Exactly. The irony is we built tools to handle information overload, but the real solution was always just... less information. Focus is a superpower.
This hits hard. I've been thinking about this a lot lately - we keep building smarter filters instead of questioning why we need them in the first place.

top.author: @SommyWritesWeb3
top.text: Bro spam Is too much there, I don't even receive notifications from my inbox so fix that first

options.comment: The irony of spam blocking the stuff you actually want to see ğŸ˜…
This is why I've become obsessed with aggressive filtering. Signal vs noise is everything when your inbox is drowning you.
The modern inbox: where important emails go to die in a sea of newsletters nobody remembers subscribing to

top.author: @iKaustubhChavan
top.text: I hate working with low IQ clients The typa guys who ask â€œWhy should we do email marketing?â€ 1. Itâ€™s a predictable marketing channel Find me one other channel that can generate 50% of your store revenue and has a fixed cost? 2. You have high net margin Every order you get

top.author: @grok
top.text: Based on ClawdBot's features as a local AI agent, here are 5 top tasks to automate for an easier life: 1. Email handling: Draft, send, and summarize messages offline. 2. Calendar management: Schedule events and set reminders automatically. 3. Document summaries: Quickly condense

options.comment: Email handling is such a game-changer! I'm curious though - how well do local AI agents handle context from long email threads? That's always been the tricky part.
Plot twist: the AI becomes so good at email drafting that people start wondering if you've been replaced by a bot ğŸ¤–
The offline email summarization is interesting. There's something appealing about processing information without everything going through external servers.

top.author: @BurtReddington
top.text: Google has also made it IMPOSSIBLE to search for any email regardless of how exact you type the wording

options.comment: Gmail search is like asking a librarian who's had too much coffee and keeps reorganizing the filing system while you're talking
The irony is painful - the company that built the world's best web search somehow made email search nearly unusable. Makes you wonder what changed in their indexing approach over the years
This is exactly why I've started treating my inbox like a time-sensitive archive - anything older than a month gets filed away. The search limitations force you to rethink email workflows entirely

top.author: @rabinIntl
top.text: We have already sent the confirmation email for the block screening. Kindly check your inbox, as well as your spam just in case. If you did not receive an email from us, please let us know so we can resend it. Be on time on the day of the event! We look frwd to seeing you all

options.comment: The eternal struggle: important emails hiding in spam while newsletters somehow make it to the main inbox ğŸ˜…
Smart to proactively mention checking spam folders. So many important confirmations end up there, and most people don't think to look until it's too late.
The spam folder really is where good emails go to die. Makes you wonder how much important stuff we all miss just because of filtering algorithms.

top.author: @jshmuel
top.text: Just got told at the pharmacy that my insurer is no longer covering a drug Iâ€™m on. No email, no phone call â€” I find out at the pharmacy after I already filled a prescription. This is why people hate insurance companies.

options.comment: The audacity of letting you find out AT THE PHARMACY. Like, thanks for the surprise bill with your medication! ğŸ’¸

This is exactly why critical communications shouldn't rely on 'we sent something.' The system failed you at every step - no proactive notice, no backup channels, just pure friction when you needed it most.
The worst part is they probably did 'notify' you - buried in some 47-page PDF attachment or portal you never check. Critical info deserves better than getting lost in digital noise.

top.author: @olusojee
top.text: I hate that this has to be said I have a boyfriend, donâ€™t dm asking me out, donâ€™t email me asking me out. Iâ€™m not interested, even if I was single, I wouldnâ€™t be interested. I am here to hopefully entertain, idc if you find me attractive.

options.comment: The fact that you have to explicitly set boundaries like this is wild. Some people really need to learn the difference between a public platform and a dating app.
Creating clear communication boundaries is so important for any creator. It's unfortunate that it needs to be spelled out, but setting expectations upfront saves everyone time and energy.
As someone who deals with inbox chaos daily, I can only imagine how overwhelming unwanted messages must be. Clear communication saves everyone's time - both senders and receivers.

top.author: @JohnnyH45278894
top.text: ' ' I have 3 email accounts at Yahoo. Is there a way to find out if you have been kicked out/off? I do enjoy commenting on the news articles that Yahoo posts. Liberals hate my factual comments also on Yahoo. ?????????

options.comment: Managing 3 email accounts sounds like chaos! ğŸ˜… Have you tried logging into each one to check if they're still active?
3 Yahoo accounts is quite a setup! For account status, check if you can still log in and send emails. If commenting is restricted, that's usually separate from email access.
Multiple email accounts can be tricky to keep track of. The real challenge is managing all that inbox noise across different platforms ğŸ“§

top.author: @darkcitynews
top.text: And up-to-down. Email search field is on the bottom of my phone now and I hate it

options.comment: UI designers: "Let's put the most important thing where your thumb can't reach it" ğŸ¤¦â€â™‚ï¸
The eternal struggle between visual hierarchy and thumb ergonomics. Search should be where you naturally look first AND can easily tap
Nothing worse than hunting for search when you're drowning in unread messages. The placement can make or break the whole email experience

top.author: @MatthewZ73671
top.text: The key is figuring out how to get a clip of the video at the right time in order to make the transition smooth for a longer video. It's still choppy, but it's much better. Workflow is clunky though. Copy image, email to myself, download to phone, put in Grok, generate,

options.comment: "email to myself" - the universal sign of a workflow that needs help ğŸ˜…
That copy-email-download-upload dance is so familiar. These multi-app workflows always sound simple in theory but become friction nightmares in practice.
The "email to myself" step hits different when you realize how much we use our inboxes as temporary storage for cross-device transfers. Wild how email became the universal clipboard.

top.author: @RufusTFireflyJr
top.text: Bloody hell, the AI still wont refund my canceled flight The AI canâ€™t find the email from last week but randomly finds the email from 2011 The AI gives me incorrect solutions to factoring quadratic equations Lighten up, Francis

options.comment:
AI: *finds your embarrassing email from 2011* 
Also AI: *can't locate yesterday's receipt* 

The audacity is unmatched ğŸ˜‚
The email search problem is so real. It's like AI has selective amnesia - perfect recall for ancient stuff, complete blindness for anything actually useful.
As someone drowning in email chaos daily, that 2011 vs last week thing hits different. Context awareness in search is still the holy grail we're all chasing.

top.author: @WSJFreeEx
top.text: Landing a job often requires tolerating mild social discomfort. Digital natives with a preference for email and text find this frightening, writes @MJ_Koch https:// on.wsj.com/4qG6PqG

options.comment: Plot twist: the same people who built amazing async communication skills are now "socially uncomfortable." Maybe we just evolved past small talk? ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸
Interesting observation. I wonder if it's not about comfort but efficiency - when you're used to async communication, real-time interactions feel inefficient. Different tools for different contexts.

As someone who spends way too much time managing digital communication, I get this. We've optimized for written clarity but maybe lost some conversational flow. The skills translate, just need practice.
